item.title: 10 Movie Anti-Heroes That Should Star In Games
item.description:
Summary

  • Rick Deckard from Blade Runner could star in a dystopian open-world, but hasn't appeared in video games yet.
  • V for Vendetta's iconic lead, V, offers an interesting premise for a video game similar to Assassin's Creed.
  • Thelma & Louise's complex character dynamic could make for an engaging female-centric co-op adventure game.

Sometimes, video game fans get a little tired of always playing as heroes like Mario or Lara Croft. Every so often, it's nice to control a character who's a little more morally ambiguous. That's why some of the most successful video games of all time star anti-heroes, which are protagonists whose heroic attributes are compounded by significant character flaws.

Video games have introduced some of the most iconic anti-heroes to fiction, including Joel Miller from The Last of Us , Shadow the Hedgehog from the Sonic franchise, and Ciri from The Witcher . However, there are also a lot of anti-heroes who originate from films (or at the very least, have been definitively interpreted by films) who would also make great video game characters someday.

10 Rick Deckard

Players Could Hunt Replicants In A Dystopian Open-World

Creator

Philip K. Dick (author), Ridley Scott (director)

Appears In

Blade Runner , Blade Runner 2049

Portrayed By

Harrison Ford

Skills/Abilities

Bounty hunting, weapon handling

Although Rick Deckard, like many of the characters on this list, originated from source material, he's best known as being portrayed by Harrison Ford in Ridley Scott's Blade Runner . A bounty hunter tracking down runaway androids (or, replicants), the film sees the character develop a strong compassion for androids, though at the start of the story he is heartless towards them.

It's surprising that, for one of the most iconic roles of Ford's, Rick Deckard hasn't made a video game appearance. There have been a few Blade Runner video games, for Commodore 64 in 1985, for PC in 1997, and for VR systems in 2018. However, none of these versions feature Rick Deckard as a playable character or even NPC.

9 V

Remember, Remember This Comic Book Anti-Hero?

Creator

Alan Moore (writer) & David Lloyd (illustrator)

Appears In

V for Vendetta

Portrayed By

Hugo Weaving

Skills/Abilities

Weapon handling, stealth, computer hacking

Alan Moore is notoriously against his own IP being adapted, which is true of 2005's V for Vendetta , despite its critical and commercial success. As a result, there has been no video game adaptation of the comic book writer's graphic novel series, but the 2005 film would be a great way for its iconic lead, the enigmatic freedom fighter V, to commit some virtual anarchy.

As a playable anti-hero, there are a lot of cool things that V could do in a video game, making it potentially similar in gameplay to the Assassin's Creed franchise. Especially given V for Vendetta being a DC Comics series, perhaps there's even a world in which V crosses paths with other iconic DC Comics characters like Batman, or even Alan Moore's own Watchmen cast.

8 Wanda Maximoff

Would It Be More Like Bayonetta Or The Sims ?

Creator

Stan Lee (writer) & Jack Kirby (illustrator), Joss Whedon (screenwriter/director)

Appears In

Captain America: The Winter Soldier, Avengers: Age of Ultron, Captain America: Civil War, Avengers: Infinity War, Avengers: Endgame, WandaVision, Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness, What If...?

Portrayed By

Elizabeth Olsen

Skills/Abilities

Witchcraft, chaos magic, dreamwalking, reality warping

It may not technically be fair to group the Scarlet Witch in with this list of strictly movie-inspired anti-heroes, given her storied history in the comics. That being said, Elizabeth Olsen has completely redefined the character of Wanda Maximoff, which means if there was ever to be a Scarlet Witch-centered video game, projects like WandaVision would make for an interesting source of inspiration.

For now, Wanda Maximoff is playable in games like Marvel Rivals and Marvel's Midnight Suns , but that's as one playable character amongst a cast of Marvel Comics heroes. Given the character's increased popularity over the years (as well as her current absence from the MCU), now's the perfect time to delight Scarlet Witch fans with a proper video game based on Olsen's portrayal.

7 Oh Dae-su

Action Video Games Would Never Be Better

Creator

Park Chan-wook (screenwriter/director)

Appears In

Oldboy

Portrayed By

Choi Min-sik

Skills/Abilities

Hand-to-hand combat, weapon handling

Park Chan-wook's 2003 film Oldboy is one of the most iconic action films of all time, but has yet to be adapted into a video game. It has, however, had an American remake from 2013 starring Josh Brolin and Elizabeth Olsen, but most fans of the original film can agree it's far inferior. Nevertheless, this revenge story would make for a perfect action video game a la Grand Theft Auto .

The film's anti-heroic protagonist, Oh Dae-su, played by Choi Min-sik, would be a particularly fun character to play, with his character getting to escape prison, hunting down his enemies, and getting into some seriously brutal fights along the way. Thankfully, there's a low bar for adapting Oldboy outside its original film, so maybe a video game adaptation is the right move.

6 The Bride

It Definitely Won't Be E For Everyone

Creator

Quentin Tarantino (screenwriter/director), Uma Thurman (actress)

Appears In

Kill Bill Vol. 1, Kill Bill Vol. 2

Portrayed By

Uma Thurman

Skills/Abilities

Weapon handling

If any of Quentin Tarantino's movies are primed for a video game adaptation, it's Kill Bill . Starring Uma Thurman as "The Bride," it's a bloody revenge story inspired by martial arts films and 1970s exploitation. It's almost shocking that the film, given its two-part release in 2003 and 2004, didn't get a video game, as it was during the height of blockbuster movies being adapted into video games.

Whether it's a side-scrolling beat-em-up or a God of War -esque hack-and-slash, The Bride's story seems like a perfectly suitable video game premise, rising up the ranks of Bill's cronies level by level. It could even be fun to see some other Tarantino figures appear as playable characters, such as Jules from Pulp Fiction , Django from Django Unchained , and Shoshanna from Inglorious Basterds .

5 John Wick

We Know Keanu Would Be Into It

Creator

Derek Kolstad (screenwriter) & Chad Stahelski (director)

Appears In

John Wick, John Wick: Chapter 2, John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum, John Wick: Chapter 4, From the World of John Wick: Ballerina, The Continental: From the World of John Wick

Portrayed By

Keanu Reeves

Skills/Abilities

Weapon handling, mixed martial arts

Even if you've never seen any John Wick films, it's not hard to see how the anti-hero could translate to a video game. Keanu Reeves is no stranger to video game adaptations, having contributed his voice to The Matrix and Constantine video games, and even for John Wick's cameo appearances in Fortnite and Payday 2 . A proper John Wick video game, however, seems severely overdue.

Perhaps with the upcoming Ballerina , starring Ana de Armas, it's the perfect opportunity to adapt the rich John Wick universe into a video game. Whether it explores some older adventures of Reeves' character prior to the events of the first film, or a completely new character who just crosses paths with John Wick, it's a great setting for a high-stakes action-adventure title.

4 Harley Quinn

Margot Robbie's Anti-Barbie Deserves Another Chance

Creator

Paul Dini (writer) & Bruce Timm (illustrator), David Ayer (screenwriter/director)

Appears In

Suicide Squad, Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn), The Suicide Squad

Portrayed By

Margot Robbie

Skills/Abilities

Weapon handling

Like Scarlet Witch, Harley Quinn technically shouldn't belong on this list. Not only did she originate in Batman: The Animated Series , but there's been plenty of video game featuring Harley, including Batman: Arkham Knight and Injustice 2 . However, like Elizabeth Olsen's Wanda, Margot Robbie's interpretation of Harley is a completely fresh take on the character.

Her portrayal has certainly rubbed off on other interpretations of Harley Quinn, including the HBO animated series starring Kaley Cuoco. Nevertheless, getting to have Margot Robbie herself reprise the character in a video game adaptation of Birds of Prey , featuring The Huntress and Black Canary as well, would be an inspired choice for DC if they have no plans of reviving Harley anytime soon.

3 The Man With No Name

Creator

Sergio Leone (screenwriter/director)

Appears In

A Fistful of Dollars, For a Few Dollars More, The Good The Bad and the Ugly

Portrayed By

Clint Eastwood

Skills/Abilities

Bounty hunting

One of the most iconic characters in the history of film is Clint Eastwood's The Man with No Name, a staple of Sergio Leone's spaghetti westerns. Video games have already perfected representing the Wild West, thanks to Red Dead Redemption , so it seems like a perfect fit to adapt Leone's film masterpieces into a video game series re-introducing audiences to Eastwood's silent sharpshooter.

Of course, the Man with No Name has inspired his fair share of video game characters, from Solid Snake of Metal Gear Solid , as well as the MS-DOS point-and-click game The Town with No Name . His last appearance in The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly saw the character ride off into the sunset to adventures unknown... maybe we could see what some of those adventures were?

2 Furiosa

Just Imagine Exploring Fury Road To Your Heart's Desire

Creator

George Miller (screenwriter/director), Brendon McCarthy (screenwriter), Nico Lauthoris (screenwriter)

Appears In

Mad Max: Fury Road, Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga

Portrayed By

Charlize Theron, Anya Taylor-Joy, Alyla Browne

Skills/Abilities

Driving, weapons handling, mechanical engineering

Charlize Theron's Furiosa from Mad Max: Fury Road was an instantly iconic movie hero, though Anya Taylor-Joy's performance in 2024's Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga proved the character's roots were as an anti-hero. Separated from her family, Furiosa becomes an undercover mechanic for Immortan Joe, before getting promoted as his Imperator by the end of the film by taking down Dementus.

Mad Max in particular is a franchise ripe for video games, featuring a vast and rich open world and epic driving sequences. The 2015 video game primarily follows Max himself, but seeing a game exploring Furiosa's story post- Mad Max: Fury Road may be the best way to continue the character's story if a film never happens, and George Miller has already named Hideo Kojima as his choice to helm that game.

1 Thelma & Louise

Creator

Callie Khouri (screenwriter), Ridley Scott (director)

Appears In

Thelma & Louise

Portrayed By

Geena Davis & Susan Sarandon

Skills/Abilities

Driving, weapons handling

Video game fans love complicated characters, and what's more complicated morally than the plot of Thelma & Louise ? The film's titular characters find themselves on the run after killing a stranger at a roadhouse, trying to make it to Mexico to evade getting caught. It's easy to imagine the film being translated into a female-centric A Way Out , with mandatory co-op playing.

In terms of gameplay, Thelma & Louise could combine the open worlds of Red Dead Redemption with the intensity of Grand Theft Auto , letting players make their way to Mexico while evading capture and, if they want, committing even more crime. Hopefully, the game's ending could leave the duo better off than the ending of the film certainly does.

item.title: Civilization 7: 10 Best Beginner Tips
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Play On Scribe Difficulty To Learn The Game
  • Read Every Tutorial Thoroughly
  • Pick A Legacy Path & Stick To It
  • Build Two Scouts Before A Granary
  • Army Commanders & Armies Are Essential
  • Towns & Cities Are Different Settlements
  • Influence Is Incredibly Important
  • After Natural Disasters, Repair Tiles
  • Keep An Eye On Your Age Progress
  • Use The Civilopedia

Despite some streamlining of mechanics, Civilization 7 feels as complex as ever. If it's your first time playing a Grand Strategy/4x game, your first time with the Civilization series, or your first time specifically playing Civilization 7 , there's a lot to learn to get good at Civ 7 .

Though the game does explain quite a lot, there are some mechanics and gameplay quirks that can be hard to understand. These best Civilization 7 starter tips will help you understand the basics of Civ 7 and help get you on your way to establishing a civilization that will stand the test of time.

1 Play On Scribe Difficulty To Learn The Game

Take Your Time & Learn The Game Before Raising Difficulty

There is no shame in taking on a lower difficulty to learn a new game, especially if you aren't familiar with it. This is especially true for the Civilization games or players who have never experienced the Grand Strategy/4x formula.

Difficulty just gives yield and combat bonuses, it doesn't actually change how AI opponents behave.

Playing on Scribe difficulty as a new Civilization 7 player is the best way to learn how Civ 7 works without being punished too much for mistakes. Even if you're an experienced Civ fan, playing on Scribe difficulty can be helpful to learn all the Civ 7 changes before jumping into Governor or higher difficulties.

2 Read Every Tutorial Thoroughly

The Civ 7 Tutorials Explain A Lot As You Progress

Compared to previous Civ games, Civilization 7 does a great job of introducing players to most mechanics via its Tutorial system. By default, Tutorials are enabled, and will guide you through almost every major mechanic in the game as they are revealed to you.

Don't skip through these menus – Civ 7 is a complicated game, and these tutorials explain the nitty-gritty of everything you need to know to play the game effectively.

3 Pick A Legacy Path & Stick To It

But Don't Neglect Other Facets Of The Game

There are four Legacy Paths, and four Victory Conditions, in Civ 7 : Cultural, Economic, Military, and Scientific. Each Age has Legacy Paths which are kind of like mini-victories with their own conditions for each age, while Victory Conditions are how you win the game in the Modern Age.

Decide which Legacy and Victory path you want to go for and do everything you can to support it to unlock Golden Age Legacy bonuses and other benefits in future Ages.

On the Age Progress screen, click the Track Progress button to see milestone goals for the Legacy Paths you want to pursue.

4 Build Two Scouts Before A Granary

Explore Your Surroundings For Narrative Events & Intel

At the start of the game, after founding your first city, produce a Scout instead of a Warrior. It will spawn on the next turn, and you can then choose between a Granary or another unit to produce.

Though Growth is incredibly important in early Civ 7 , Scouts can reveal Discoveries and the world map to give you more information on your surroundings. Build another Scout and send them in the opposite direction to your first Scout unit and explore your surroundings – two Scouts means double the Discoveries. Use the "Search" action to reveal these in the nearby Fog of War.

5 Army Commanders & Armies Are Essential

Independent Hostiles Will Be A Thorn In Your Side

In previous Civilization games players could easily get through an entire run without hardly any investment in their military presence. Things are different in Civ 7 : one of the best tips for beginners and experienced Civ fans alike is to always have a standing army.

Hostile Independent units will relentlessly attack any settlement that is undefended, and enemy players may declare War on you and send armies of their own your way. Combat is a constant threat in Civ 7 , but if you build your military out and have an Army Commander to lead them, you should be able to deal with invaders.

6 Towns & Cities Are Different Settlements

Towns Fuel Cities, Cities Have A Production Queue

When you found a settlement aside from your founding City in Civ 7 , you will create a Town. Towns are different from Cities in a few key ways. They do not have a production queue, and you can only purchase buildings for them with Gold. They don't have as many Resouce slots as cities, and can only use Bonus resources. Until they reach 7 Population, they can't do anything but grow and send gold back to your Cities.

You can upgrade a Town to a City with a hefty sum of gold, but you can also set a Town Focus at 7 Population, which specialized the town in one of several ways. Don't go into Civ 7 expecting every settlement to work the same way – think of Towns as being a funnel for resources to your Cities.

7 Influence Is Incredibly Important

Befriend Hostiles, Establish Endeavors, War Support, & More

One of the new Yields in Civ 7 is Influence, which is tied to the new Diplomacy and trading system. Inluence is used for a huge variety of important things that essentially all boil down to trade and relationship-building. Influence is very powerful – when used correctly.

It can be used to grant yourself War Support, befriend hostile and friendly independent people to become their Suzerain, to fund Endeavors and other Diplomatic actions between Leaders, and it can even be used to reject a Denounce action.

Don't underestimate this resource, and use it wisely to quite literally Influence the world as you see fit.

8 After Natural Disasters, Repair Tiles

Using Gold Or Production, Restore Tiles Destroyed By Disasters Or Pillaging

Natural Disasters can happen at any time. Random squall thunderstorms, river floods, volcanic eruptions, blizzards, and other Natural Disasters can destroy tiles and even damage units.

After a Natural Disaster occurs, click on the affected city and use your Gold or Production to repair the destroyed tiles. While destroyed, these tiles will not grant any bonuses, so it's very important to get these fixed quickly.

It costs way less Gold relative to the Production cost to repair a tile, and will repair a tile instantly rather than over several turns.

9 Keep An Eye On Your Age Progress

And Track Your Quests To Finish Legacy Paths

As you progress through Legacy Paths and establish a civilization to stand the test of time, the Age Progression (on the top-left of the screen) will continue to advance. At about 60% through the age, a Crisis will begin, forcing every player to adopt negative Social Policies. If you keep an eye on the Age Progression, you can prepare for the inevitable negative consequences.

When a player meets a Legacy Path milestone (or finishes a Future Tech/Civic research), the Age Progression will suddenly get boosted. Future Tech and Civics advance the age by about 5 to 8 percent.

If you are already done with your path, research these over rand over to rapidly advance the age and lock out other players from getting a victory condition.

10 Use The Civilopedia

It's There For A Reason!

If you are having trouble understanding anything in-game, the ultimate guide to all Civilization 7 beginner tips is actually available in-game via the Civilopedia. The Civilopedia can be accessed by clicking on the golden book icon on the top-right of the screen.

The Civilopedia contains entries for just about every mechanic, unit, tile, and other gameplay feature of Civ 7 . If you don't understand what something is, or want to learn more about a Civ or Leader's history, check out this useful in-game resource.

item.title: 7 Best Open-World Games That Focus On Boss Fights, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Some open-world games feature frequent and diverse boss battles, keeping players engaged and continuously testing their skills.
  • Rise of the Ronin and Ghost of Tsushima emphasize human bosses, showcasing a wide variety of their weapons and combat styles.
  • Elden Ring stands out with its vast roster of unique bosses, delivering a challenging yet rewarding experience.

Boss encounters are relatively rare in open-world games, as players typically face the most dangerous foes only occasionally while exploring vast maps. However, some titles break this mold by incorporating frequent and diverse boss battles, challenging players at nearly every turn, whether during the main story, side quests, or simple exploration.

While open-world games that fully revolve around boss fights remain uncommon, many titles introduce unique approaches that make such encounters stand out. For example, in The Witcher 3 , each monster boss requires careful preparation and strategy, while in Ghost of Tsushima , one-on-one duels feel distinct from the rest of the gameplay, offering cinematic and intense combat moments. Below, we'll explore some of the best open-world games that revolve around boss battles, ranking them based on how frequent, diverse, engaging, or unique such encounters are.

Honorable mentions:

These games might be worth considering for players looking for extra titles focusing on monster bosses. However, since they are not true open-world games but instead feature large, separated zones, they are only worth mentioning:

  • Monster Hunter World
  • Wild Hearts
  • Dauntless
  • Monster Hunter Rise

7 Rise Of The Ronin

Staying True To Its Soulslike Roots With Dozens Of Human Bosses

Rise of the Ronin strikes a balance between a traditional open-world action RPG and a soulslike, while also being deeply rooted in its historical setting. As a result, players primarily face human opponents rather than fantastical creatures. However, the game still offers plenty of unique human bosses scattered across Yokohama, Edo, and Kyoto, each wielding distinct weapons, combat styles, and backstories for those interested in the lore.

While Rise of the Ronin isn't strictly focused on boss encounters, the sheer number of powerful enemies found in dungeons, towers, and abandoned settlements ensures a steady challenge. Combined with the game's diverse combat system, these encounters provide engaging and varied battles throughout the entire journey.

6 Dragon's Dogma 2

Colossal Bosses Delivering Unique And Unforgettable Encounters

While Dragon's Dogma 2 follows the familiar formula of an open-world action RPG, its boss encounters truly set it apart. Though it may not feature as many large-scale boss fights as some other titles listed below, each battle feels dynamic and memorable, thanks to the game's combat system, which allows players to climb enemies and deliver devastating strikes.

The game boasts a variety of mythological creatures to slay, including dragons, minotaurs, griffins, ogres, cyclopes, chimeras, and many more. While players will spend much of their time exploring the vast world and dealing with smaller, more persistent foes like goblins, Dragon's Dogma 2 earns its place on any action fan's list for its exhilarating boss battles alone.

5 Horizon Forbidden West

Formidable And Unique Machine Bosses Pose A Serious Threat

Building on its predecessor, Horizon Forbidden West introduces an even greater variety of unique machine enemies to discover and battle across its vast and exotic open world. Aloy's combat arsenal has been expanded with new weapons and abilities, while the machines themselves, such as the Tideripper, Tremortusk, and Grimhorn, are now larger, faster, and more aggressive than ever.

With the addition of the Burning Shores expansion, Forbidden West features over 20 unique machine bosses (human bosses excluded), each requiring a strategic approach, careful study of their weaknesses, and constant upgrades to Aloy's gear to even stand a chance against these Apex predators. Fortunately, the rewards for defeating these formidable foes are well worth the effort, offering some of the rarest and most valuable upgrade materials in the game.

4 Shadow Of The Colossus

A World Where There's Nothing To Do But Defeat 16 Unique Colossi

Arguably the most fitting entry on this list, Shadow of the Colossus stands out as a uniquely structured open-world action game. Unlike most titles in the genre, its world is devoid of traditional activities: there are absolutely no ordinary enemies to fight, no side quests to complete, and almost no treasures to uncover. Instead, the sole objective is to locate and defeat 16 colossal beings in a desperate attempt to bring back a lost love.

Despite its seemingly minimalistic design, Shadow of the Colossus delivers an unforgettable and deeply resonant experience. Each boss fight presents a unique puzzle, requiring players to decipher the specific strategy needed to take down each towering foe. Beyond its gameplay, the game's themes of loss, desperation, and sacrifice leave a lasting emotional impact, making it one of the most haunting and powerful open-world adventures that players can find.

3 Ghost Of Tsushima

Features Dedicated, Cinematic Boss Duels

Ghost of Tsushima stands out as a very special open-world game when it comes to boss encounters. Throughout his journey, Jin Sakai faces dozens of elite swordsmen, including former friends, allies, and legendary samurai masters guarding powerful weapons, charms, or armor sets. Each of these confrontations unfolds as a cinematic sword duel, reminiscent of a fighting game, where players must engage in intense one-on-one battles, skillfully countering enemy attacks and mastering the art of the katana.

These duels serve as the ultimate test of a player's combat prowess, locking the camera perspective and enforcing an honorable, skill-based fight without any alternative tactics. Beyond their mechanical depth, these encounters are seamlessly woven into the story, reinforcing Jin Sakai's character and his struggle to uphold the way of the samurai while protecting Tsushima.

2 The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

Hunt And Slay Dozens Of Distinct Monster Bosses

A reigning champion of the open-world action-RPG genre for years, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is renowned for its vast bestiary, even beyond its major story-driven boss fights against the formidable Wild Hunt horsemen like Nithral, Caranthir, and Imlerith. Stepping into the shoes of a witcher, players must track and hunt unique monsters, including werewolves, giants, griffins, wights, and vampires, carefully studying their weaknesses, gathering clues, and preparing the right tools for the job.

On lower difficulties, these battles rarely pose a serious challenge unless there's a significant level gap. However, playing The Witcher 3 on higher difficulties has its positives, requiring players to master every aspect of Geralt's arsenal — from weapon oils and elixirs to tactical use of magical signs. Mastering the game's combat system is a rewarding process that makes living in this perilous world much more immersive.

1 Elden Ring

An Open-World Soulslike Featuring Hundreds Of Unique Bosses

When it comes to open-world boss encounters, nothing can compare to Elden Ring , proudly standing in a league of its own. While its map isn't the largest in the genre, it is densely packed with formidable creatures, each wielding deadly weapons, unique skills, or devastating magical abilities capable of annihilating the Tarnished in an instant. Nearly every cave, dungeon, castle, or tower houses a powerful, often unseen foe, though some degree of repetition exists.

As one of the few true open-world soulslike games with no difficulty options, Elden Ring 's bosses can be daunting — especially for newcomers. However, as players refine their combat skills, discover and upgrade their ideal weapons, and learn the intricate rules of the Lands Between, the game unfolds into one of the most diverse, exhilarating, and rewarding journeys in gaming so far. Players definitely won't soon forget their first victories over legendary Demigods like Godrick the Grafted or Rykard, Lord of Blasphemy.

item.title: Civilization 7: Maya Civ Strategies & Tips
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Maya Civ Overview
  • Best Maya Leader Pairings
  • Maya Civ Strategy & Walkthrough

In Civilization 7 , Maya is one of the ten Civilizations you can start as in the Antiquity Age. As a Diplomatic and Scientific civ, Maya strategies tend to revolve around its potential for strong Science output, but there's more to it than just b-lining every Tech.

To help players succeed in the Antiquity age with this Civ, this Civ 7 Maya guide explains all of the Maya unique abilities, units, and buildings, how to take advantage of its unique playstyle, and offers advice on the best Civ 7 Maya strategies to win a Legacy Path for the Antiquity Age.

Maya Civ Overview

Maya Abilities, Attributes, Units, Buildings, Civics, & More

The people lay these stones as a pathway to the heavens.

Come, kuhul ajaw, and assume the world's throne.

Maya Unique Ability: Skies of Itzamna

  • Skies of Itsamna : The Palace gains +0.5 Science for adjacent Vegetated terrain.

The Palace only appears in your founding city, so make sure you capitalize by looking for a place with lots of Vegetated tiles around a single strong founding city tile.

Maya Unique Civic Trees

  • Rain of Chaac : Unlocks the K'uh Nah. Grants the Altar a Science bonus for adjacent Vegetated tiles. Grants the 'Pet Kot' tradition, which grants Science to all Vegetated tiles in Cities when slotted.
  • Lords of Xibalba : Unlocks the Jalaw. Hul'che and Jaguar Slayers gain Stealth in Vegetated tiles. Grants the 'Miracles of the Twins' tradition, which grants a +3 combat bonus against wounded units.
  • Calendar Round : Gain Culture equal to 15% of a Technology cost, and Science equal to 15% of a Civic cost. Mastery boosts Settlement Limit, adds traditions that grant Science and Culture to Happiness buildings.

Generally, the best Maya strategy when it comes to civics is to research Rain of Chaac first, to get the Science bonus for Vegetated tiles from the Kuh'nah.

Maya Unique Units: Jaguar Slayer & Hul'che

  • Jaguar Slayer : Mayan unique Recon unit that can initiate combat and comes with a Trap, which stops movement and deals damage if an enemy unit steps on it.

The Jaguar Slayer is an extremely powerful Recon unit for the early game. It's highly advised to train two of these first to get as many Discoveries and explore as wide an area as possible when you start a game as the Maya.

Set up some traps around your cities to inhibit encroaching armies with the Jaguar Slayer's unique ability.

  • Hul'che : Mayan unique Ranged unit, can see through Vegetation and is not inhibited by Vegetated tiles

Build at least two of these for each Settlement to defend against Hostile Independents who won't be able to retaliate until they get through the surrounding terrain.

Maya Unique Infrastructure: Jalaw, K'uh Nah, Uwaybil K'uh Unique Quarter

  • Jalaw : Happiness building that grants Culture Adjacency bonus for Quarters
  • K'uh Nah : Science building that grants Science Adjacency for Vegetated tiles
  • Uwaybil K'uh : Maya Unique Quarter. Grants Production equal to 15% of the Science cost of a Technology in this city. Created by combining Jalaw and K'uh Nah in the same tile.

The Jalaw and K'uh Nah are great unique Maya buildings on their own, but when combined, they make for one of the best Antiquity age Quarters. The Uwaybil K'uh can help you rapidly develop new Cities – if your Science output is high enough to make a meaningful difference.

Maya Associated Wonder: Mundo Perdido

  • Mundo Perdido Wonder Effect : Increased Happiness and Science on all Tropical tiles in this City. Must be placed on a Tropical tile.

It's not too important to get this Wonder, but if you have the production to get it done quickly (alongside your 30% boost for this Wonder specifically as the Maya), it can be helpful, especially if you have lots of Tropical tiles.

Maya Starting Bias: Vegetated Tropical

The Vegetated Tropical starting bias benefits from the Mundo Perdido wonder (Tropical) and the Maya unique civ ability (Vegetated terrain). If you don't have much Vegetation or Tropical tiles around your starting location, it might be worth restarting.

Best Maya Leader Pairings

Benjamin Franklin

  • Increased Science per Age on Production buildings in Cities.
  • Boosted Production towards Production Buildings, and increased Science per Age for every Endeavor started.
  • Multiple Endeavors of the same type can be started.

Benjamin Franklin is one of the best Maya leaders in Civ 7 for the Science victory, when paired with a secondary Diplomatic/Economic approach. In Antiquity, you will be able to produce Production-based buildings significantly faster, and gain a nifty Science boost every time you complete an Endeavor.

If you go with Ben Franklin, make sure you build out your Influence and are careful with how you spend it. Set up as many deals as possible throughout the Age to maximize Science in future Ages.

Confucius

  • +25% Growth Rate in all cities
  • +2 Science for every Specialist

Confucius is a simple leader yet one of the best Leaders for the Science victory. Having 25% extra Growth in all Cities is massive in Antiquity, and you'll be able to acquire Resources and slot Specialists significantly faster than any other Civ because of it.

In Exploration, the Science Legacy Path becomes trivial with the extra Science on every Specialist. Also, the Ming Exploration civ unlocks by playing as Confucius automatically, which makes the Exploration Science legacy path even easier.

Maya Civ Strategy & Walkthrough

Best Maya Legacy Path: Science

Civ 7 Maya General Strategy

The Maya civ is an Antiquity Age civ with a Diplomatic and Scientific focus, but for the best Maya strategy, Civ 7 players should aim for the Scientific Legacy path . The Maya's huge Science potential in the early game and sturdy Jaguar Slayer units make for a combination of fast Tech research and rapid Codex acquisition .

At first, focus exclusively on Growth – generally, Growth should be your main priority for the first few dozen turns. Once you unlock Writing, begin to focus on building out your Science output.

Try to reach your Settlement limit whenever possible to maximize the space to build important Scientific Legacy buildings.

Once you have good Gold income, start focusing exclusively on building Science buildings (like the Library and Academy) to house your Codexes and rush the Science legacy path. Gold will let you upgrade Towns to Cities to house more Codexes, and will let you purchase Buildings like the Library instantly.

Scientific Legacy Walkthrough & Starting Tips

To win as the Maya civ, or rather to get the Scientific Legacy Path victory for the Antiquity Age, a few things need to happen. Remember to check the "Track Progress" button in the Age Progress screen to see reminders for what to do next.

  • First, you must research Writing and build a Library to meet the first goal.
  • Then, you have to get the Writing Mastery, research Mathematics, and build an Academy to reach the second progression point.
  • To complete the Science Legacy Path in Antiquity, you must find and display 10x Codices in your empire.

When you start as the Maya, ensure that you have at least three or four Vegetated tiles around your initial starting location , and have Tropical tiles nearby , too. Vegetated and Tropical tiles benefit the most from the unique Maya civ abilities.

Found your starting city surrounded by as many Vegetated tiles as possible to boost your Science output from the get-go. Immediately send out a Jaguar Slayer and train a second one to go in the opposite direction.

Every few turns, move your Jaguar Slayers one tile instead of two and use the "Search" ability . This scouts out the fog of war for nearby Discoveries and highlights them. B-line your way to these, as there is a high chance for these Discoveries to contain a Codex .

Having two Scouts makes it more likely you will get Codex early, and you can nab Discoveries before opponents.

Tech & Codex Progression

You can also get Codices in Civ 7 from researching certain Tech and Civic Masteries . Hover over the Masteries in each of these trees to see if they will grant a Codex on completion. Because some Civics grant Codices, Civ 7 Maya strategies should not completely ignore Culture output .

You can only slot one Codex at first, so start working towards the Writing Technology as soon as possible . This unlocks the Library, which adds a few more Codex slots, and boosts your Science output.

After that, aim to get Mathematics researched as soon as possible to get Academies for even more Codex slots .

Place the Library and Academy on spots next to at least two Resources to boost their Science Adjacency bonuses . Aim for a spot with an empty tile next to it to place the Mundo Perdido on later, which will grant even more Science.

Maya Unique Civics & Buildings

After getting Writing, though, if your Culture is high enough it's a good idea to start researching your unique Maya Civics . Aim to complete these before about 50% through the Antiquity Age to get the most benefit.

  • Start with Rain of Chaac to get the Social Policy that increases Science for Vegetated tiles, then get Lords of Xibalba to unlock the second unique Maya building.
  • Place both the Jalaw and the K'uh Nah in the same tile to get the unique Maya district and start boosting your Production every time you research a Tech.
    • The tile with the Jalaw and K'uh Nah should be surrounded by Vegetated Tiles for the best Science adjacency.

When you unlock Calendar Round, build the Mundo Perdido Wonder to get more Science from Tropical Tiles, then metaphorically sit back and relax as the Science just pours in.

Other Maya Civ Tips

The Antiquity Age Maya Civ 7 strategy is strongest when you are passive. Stay on top of your Influence accrual to begin Scientific and Happiness Endeavors and befriend Independent People – especially if they are hostile.

It's important to maintain good relationships with the AI opponents so that you can avoid going to war and can benefit from Alliance-based bonuses in later ages. Set up Happiness and Scientific Endeavors, Support their deals, and don't be a nuisance to avoid conflict with other players.

With high Science and a good Economy, you should be able to weather any potential invader.

Keep at least two Hul'che units in each settlement to play defense, and get an Army Commander to enhance them if things are getting hostile. These units can ward off most potential attackers.

You can get benefits from each type of Legacy Path , so be sure to aim for at least one or two other Legacy Path milestones and round out your foundation for the Exploration Age. If you focus entirely on Science you won't have many Legacy Path rewards to choose from at the end of the Age.

If you spend most of your time developing Science, but also wisely place Resources and establish lots of settlements, you will also get Military and Economic points to spend at the end of the Age.

You should also look for powerful Natural Wonders like the Grand Canyon to boost your Science yields even further. The Grand Canyon adds Science to every tile in a settlement, which can make for an absolutely enormous Science push if you get it done early.

As long as you focus on Science and balance out your Culture and Gold yields at the same time (to get masteries for Codices, and more slots for Codices in Cities ) you should sail through the Science Legacy Path goals and win a Science Legacy Path victory as the Maya, setting the stage for a very strong Exploration Age start.

item.title: Deadlock: Calico Build Guide
item.description:
Calico is one of the four new characters that recently made its way to the primary roaster of heroes in Deadlock . Previously called Nano, this hero excels at creating chaos on the map by offering ganking support. With the right items, she can dive in, get kills, and disappear off the map before the enemy team has a chance to react.

Alternatively, with the right items, you can transform this hero into a massive bruiser who dives into the thick of the fight and forces down objectives. But most players still go for the spirit scaling assassin build because of its sheer damage output. In this guide, we'll show you how this Calico build works in Deadlock and the items you need to build on the hero to bring it online.

Deadlock Calico Overview & Ability Details

Despite a weak laning presence, Calico specializes in 1-vs-1 encounters. Her ability to disappear off the map and quickly offer ganking support to the side lanes makes her a formidable hero to add to your mains. Healing is extremely strong in Deadlock , and Calico's self heal with Leaping Slash is one of the strongest in the game. While her primary fire isn't all too good with a small magazine size, with a few items, it scales well into the mid and late game.

Here's a quick overview of Calico's abilities in Deadlock :

Ability Name

Effects

Upgrades

Gloom Bombs

Throw a cluster of bombs that detonate after a delay, dealing Spirit Damage.

  • Spirit Damage: 60 (0.8x spirit scaling modifier)
  • Bomb Count: 4
  • Range: 2.5m
  • Cooldown: 10s

1 AP: +20 Damage

2 AP: -3s Cooldown

5 AP: +2 Bomb Count

Leaping Slash

Dash forward before slashing all enemies in a circle, dealing Light Melee Damage. Heal a small amount of health on hero hit. Enemies hit by multiple Gloom Bombs take 50% decreased damage.

  • Heal Amount: 50 (1.6x spirit scaling modifier)
  • Dash Range: 9m
  • Slash Radius: 4.5m
  • Cooldown: 11s

1 AP: +30 Heal Amount

2 AP: +75 Damage

5 AP: -50% Cooldown on Hit

Ava

Turn to shadows and possess Ava. You gain Movement Speed and become Hidden on the Minimap, but cannot attack or cast abilities.

  • Move Speed Bonus: 65%
  • Buff Duration: 15s
  • Cooldown: 45s

1 AP: +20s Buff Duration

2 AP: +45% Move Speed Bonus

5 AP: -15s Cooldown, Gain 30 Health Regen during Ava.

Return to Shadows

Instantly turn to shadows, becoming Untargetabble, gaining Movement Speed, and dealing Damage. After 3s, return from the shadows, dealing Damage again.

  • Channel Duration: 3s
  • Spirit Damage: 150 (0.655x spirit scaling modifier)
  • Move Speed Bonus: 50%
  • Damage Radius: 7m
  • Cooldown: 90s

1 AP: -30s Cooldown

2 AP: +80 Damage

5 AP: Reset all cooldowns and gain 30% damage amp for 5s.

You can't use Ava for 5 seconds after taking damage from an enemy hero. Ava's bonus movement speed also gets reduced by 50% after taking damage from an enemy hero.

Calico Build Guide (Ability Order & Item Progression) in Deadlock

You can either play Calico as a tanky frontline like Abrams, who excels in staying in the thick of the battle, or as a sneaky assassin who can roam around the map, cleaning up enemy heroes and split-pushing the lanes. For this build, we'll go with her ganker playstyle, as that is the one that's more popular in the current meta. Besides, you won't have to rely much on your team with this build.

Calico can be played both in a Solo and Dual lane.

The build utilizes Calico's high spirit scaling on Gloom Bombs and Leaping Slash to bump up its damage output and heal. Although you'll mostly be building Spirit Items, you'll also have to invest in a few Weapon and Vitality items to fill out the slots and round up your build. Most of your Flex Slots, however, will be reserved for Spirit items.

Here's how this build works:

Calico Ability Order

When playing as Calico, you'll want to start the laning stage with a point in your Gloom Bombs. Because of her weak primary weapon, you'll have to rely on this ability to poke at your lane opponents. Unlock Leaping Slash next, followed by Ava. Unlock your ultimate as soon as it becomes available for a massive power spike.

You can use Gloom Bombs to quickly farm Jungle camps.

As for point allocation, you'll want to invest 1 AP into Gloom Bombs early to get the bonus damage. Invest 3 AP into Leaping Slash to unlock its level 2 upgrade. Afterward, max out your ultimate to activate the damage amp and cooldown refresh. Max out Gloom Bombs next and take the final upgrade of Leaping Slash. Start putting points into Ava once the rest of your abilities are upgraded fully.

The bonus damage from the Gloom Bombs upgrade applies to each individual bomb.

Calico Item Progression

Calico doesn't require as many items to become effective when you're playing as a ganker. Similar to Lash, with a couple of key items and points in your abilities, you'll quickly start to output insane levels of damage with the hero. Here are the items you'll want to pick up on Calico throughout the game.

Early Game:

  • Ammo Scavenger
  • Spirit Strike
  • Melee Lifesteal
  • Hollow Point Ward
  • Basic Magazine
  • Extra Health
  • Cold Front
  • Mystic Shot
  • Extra Spirit

In the laning stage as Calico, your primary focus is to overcome her weak trading potential. Ammo Scavenger, Spirit Strike, and Melee Lifesteal will give you a strong laning presence, allowing you to poke your opponent. Ammo Scavenger's passive ability to gain back ammo is essential for the hero because of her small magazine size. Melee Lifesteal stacks with the healing from Leaping Strike, making it a strong combo to utilize in the laning stage.

With Hollow Point Ward and Basic Magazine, you'll significantly beef up your weapon damage potential. Extra Health and Extra Spirit give you some basic boosts to your stat, while Mystic Shot adds bonus spirit damage. Finally, go with Cold Front as an additional way to inflict AOE damage on the hero.

You can use Cold Front even when transformed into Ava.

Mid Game

  • Torment Pulse
  • Soul Shredder Bullets
  • Healing Booster
  • Healbane
  • Spirit Snatch
  • Lifestrike
  • Improved Spirit
  • Surge of Power

You'll want to unlock Flex Slots as early as possible to utilize Calico's full potential. If you've got at least one Flex Slot unlocked, go for Torment Pulse. It's a bit expensive, but this one item will significantly beef up your damage output, allowing you to passively deal Spirit Damage to any nearby enemy units.

Soul Shredder Bullets is an amazing pickup, further adding to the damage amp from your ultimate ability. Healing Booster, Healbane, and Lifestrike are essential Vitality items that'll allow you to tank damage and stay in the fight for longer. If you've maxed out Gloom Bombs by this point, go for Surge of Power and imbue the ability with this item. Upgrade Extra Spirits to Improved Spirits next.

Late Game

  • Bullet/Spirit Armor
  • Improved Bullet/Spirit Armor
  • Mystic Vulnerability
  • Boundless Spirit
  • Colossus/Debuff Reducer/Debuff Remover
  • Warp Stone

There are a few more items you'll want to buy to wrap up this build. First off, you'll want to invest in either Bullet or Spirit Armor, depending on the enemy team matchup, and upgrade it to the next level. This will significantly beef up your survivability in one-on-one fights and help you kill your opponents without losing too much HP.

Go for Spirit Armor if the enemy team primarily has Spirit Damage and Bullet Armor against weapon damage.

Mystic Vulnerability fills up your next Flex Slot, but you can also sell Ammo Scavenger at this point if you don't have extra slots unlocked. Go with Colossus or Debuff Reducer/Remover if you're having trouble playing around enemy crowd-control abilities. Boundless Spirit is an amazing late-game pickup for the additional Spirit Power. Warp Stone can also be a good pickup if you need some extra mobility to catch heroes like Pocket.

Deadlock is an extremely dynamic game where you can try out a lot of different builds on the heroes, depending on your playstyle. The Calico build that we discussed specializes in duels and can outfight most heroes in the game without too much trouble. But keep in mind this is not the only way to play the hero. As you start getting familiar with the hero's abilities, feel free to try out different item combinations to see exactly what this hero is capable of.
